description: From Latin animus (“the mind, in a great variety of meanings: the rational soul in man, intellect, consciousness, will, intention, courage, spirit, sensibility, feeling, passion, pride, vehemence, wrath, etc., the breath, life, soul”), closely related to anima, which is a feminine form; see anima.

adjectives.description: animastic (comparative more animastic, superlative most animastic)

entries.meaning: (rare) Pertaining to or possessing an animate nonphysical nature; having a mental or spiritual nature.
examples: But we employ fables in an animastic mode, when we contemplate the energies of the soul.

entries.meaning: Relating to mind or spirit; spiritual.
